candidates.title: chore: improve CI
candidates.body:
# Description

Make CI faster and more maintainable.

Notable changes:
- Aggregate test, fmt, lint, e2e into `ci.yml` and result in one required status `ci:required`.
- Parallelize `examples.yml` and run fmt for them.
- ic-cdk-optimizer build on three platforms; all other CI jobs run only on linux.

candidates.title: feat: interface to query ledger blocks
candidates.body:
This change introduces a new interface in the `ic-ledger-types` package to query
blocks (the [`query_blocks` endpoint](https://github.com/dfinity/ic/blob/7456121c506acaaa79d2251b803709abf0bdcbb3/rs/rosetta-api/ledger_canister/ledger.did#L236)
of the ICP ledger).

I tested the interface by deploying a canister that fetches ICP ledger blocks on the mainnet (see https://github.com/dfinity/examples/pull/247/).

# Checklist:

- [x] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation.

upgrading the certified assets canister to a newer version of
ic-certified-assets.

candidates.title: feat: adds serialization-agnostic API for reading arguments and replying
candidates.body: This patch makes `arg_data_raw` public and adds `reply_raw` to provide a way to read the raw argument bytes of a method and to reply with raw bytes.

candidates.title: chore(SDK-417): add an e2d test for async cleanup
candidates.body:
This change adds an end-to-end test checking that the CDK frees
canister resources if the canister traps after an async call.

This feature was implemented in https://github.com/dfinity/cdk-rs/pull/232.
The test revealed that the feature is broken, so this PR also fixes the
cleanup logic to make the test pass.

candidates.title: chore(SDK-417): e2e tests for Rust CDK
candidates.body:
This change introduces a framework for writing end-to-end tests for
Rust CDK.

The tests use a simple test framework developed for the IC repo,
`ic-state-machine-tests`. The framework provides an easy-to-use
interface to messaging and execution layer. The Wasm execution happens
directly in the test process.

Running `cargo test` in the repo will automatically trigger these tests.

The compilation of ic-state-machine tests takes a while, but incremental
builds are fast (10 sec). Single test execution is also relatively
fast (10 sec for debug test run, 2.5 sec in release test run).

The overall approach to testing:

  1. Write a simple canister that uses the desired feature and put it
     under tests/canisters.

  2. Add a test in tests/tests/e2e.rs that builds, installs, and
     interacts with the canister.

candidates.title: feat: Add `BufferedStableWriter` which aims to minimise system calls
candidates.body:
# Description

This adds a new stable memory writer called `BufferedStableWriter` which first buffers bytes in canister memory and only flushes those bytes to stable memory when the buffer becomes full.
Allocating additional memory and making system calls (`stable_grow` and `stable_write`) are both expensive operations, this writer minimises both.

# How Has This Been Tested?

There are unit test which cover the new `BufferedStableWriter` and the existing `StableWriter`.
I have also tested this locally and have successfully performed a few canister upgrades, adding data between each upgrade.

# Checklist:

- [x] The title of this PR complies with [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/en/v1.0.0/).
- [x] I have edited the CHANGELOG accordingly.
- [ ] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation.

candidates.title: chore: Remove default features
candidates.body:
This PR removes the default features from `ic-cdk` and `ic-cdk-macros` which in turn enable the `cdk` feature in `candid`.

### Motivation

The default features are tricky because they end up getting enabled in situations where you don't want them to, e.g. if you have a dependency which in turn depends on candid but without enabling this feature, then you end up with code that doesn't compile (because there are two crates pulling the same one, once with the feature on and once without). This results in not being able to use `ic-cdk` and `ic-cdk-macros` with e.g. parts of the `ic` repository which makes certain things, that should be easy quite, hard to implement in your canister. 

Even worse, if you try to disable default features when importing `ic-cdk` and `ic-cdk-macros`, you actually still end up enabling the default features because `ic-cdk-macros` depends on `ic-cdk` with default features on. So, even if you are trying to be extra careful and disable default features everywhere in your dependencies, you are still stuck with them.

### Proposed solution

The proposed solution is to remove the default features from `ic-cdk` and `ic-cdk-macros`. This results in having to add `candid` as an explicit dependency in your projects (see some of the examples which are fixed in this patch) but this doesn't seem to be a big burden given the headaches that one saves.

candidates.title: feat: a library of types for communicating with the ICP ledger
candidates.body:
This change introduces a new library, ic-ledger-types, which defines
types for communicating with the ICP ledger canister from Rust canisters:
  * `Address` and related types define methods to compute ledger
    addresses from principals and subaccounts.
  * `AccountBalanceArgs` and `TransferArgs` define structures that
    should be used for sending requests to the ledger canister.
  * MAINNET_LEDGER_CANISTER_ID defines the principal of the ledger
    canister on the mainnet.
